questions.text: When placenta invades myometrium but doesn't penetrate serosa such type of adherent placenta is called:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Adherent placenta, also known as morbidly adherent placenta, refers to abnormal attachment of the placenta to the uterine wall due to defective decidua basalis. When the placenta invades into the myometrium but does not penetrate the uterine serosa, it is classified as placenta increta. This condition is more severe than placenta accreta and can result in massive postpartum hemorrhage, often requiring hysterectomy at the time of delivery.

Clinical Features:

  • Antepartum hemorrhage: May occur in late pregnancy, though not always present.
  • Failure of placental separation after delivery.
  • Severe postpartum hemorrhage (PPH): Typically occurs when attempts are made to remove the placenta manually.
  • Shock: May be out of proportion to visible blood loss.
  • No plane of cleavage between placenta and uterus during manual removal.
  • History of risk factors:
    • Previous cesarean section
    • Placenta previa
    • Prior uterine surgeries (e.g., curettage, myomectomy)

Investigation Findings:

Antenatal Diagnosis:

  • Ultrasound (preferably transvaginal):
    • Loss of clear zone between placenta and myometrium
    • Thinning of the myometrium over the placenta
    • Turbulent lacunar blood flow within the placenta on color Doppler
    • Placental bulge or extension into uterine wall
  • MRI (if ultrasound is inconclusive):
    • Better defines the depth and topography of invasion
    • Especially useful in posterior placenta and to differentiate increta from percreta

Management:

Antenatal Period:

  • Planned delivery at tertiary care center with availability of blood products, ICU, and surgical expertise
  • Timing: Elective cesarean hysterectomy at 34-36 weeks in stable cases, after corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity
  • Avoid manual removal of placenta during delivery

Intraoperative Management:

  • Cesarean hysterectomy (preferred): Uterus with placenta in situ is removed to prevent massive hemorrhage
  • Conservative management (selected cases only):
    • Placenta left in situ
    • Uterotonics, methotrexate may be considered (controversial)
    • Close follow-up with imaging and monitoring for infection, bleeding, or sepsis

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Placenta accreta (Option A):
This is the least severe form of morbidly adherent placenta. In this condition, the placental villi attach directly to the superficial myometrium without actual invasion into it.

Placenta percreta (Option C):
This is the most severe form, where the placenta penetrates through the myometrium and uterine serosa, and may even invade adjacent organs such as the bladder.

Subamniotic abruption (Option D):
This is a type of placental abruption, not an adherent placenta. It involves bleeding between the amniotic membrane and the fetal surface of the placenta and is unrelated to abnormal placental invasion.

choices.text: 32 completed weeks after steroid coverage

questions.text: Ideal time for delivery in case of Placenta accreta spectrum is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

PAS should be planned for delivery at 34-36 weeks. Ideally planned caesarean hysterectomy is done for such cases with a multidisciplinary approach.

questions.text: Most common cause of retained placenta is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common cause of retained placenta is uterine atony, which refers to the failure of the uterus to contract adequately after delivery. In a normal third stage of labor, uterine contractions help shear the placenta off the uterine wall and expel it. When the uterus remains relaxed or flabby (atonic), this process is disrupted, and the placenta may remain partially or completely retained. This is the leading cause, particularly in settings with prolonged labor, overdistension of the uterus (e.g., multiple pregnancy, polyhydramnios), or use of uterine relaxants.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Adherent placenta (PAS) (Option B):
While placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) is a significant cause of retained placenta, it is less common than atonic uterus. PAS involves abnormal placental adherence due to absence of decidua basalis and is usually diagnosed antenatally.

Presence of constriction ring (Option C):
A constriction ring (Schröder's ring) may trap part of the placenta or fetus, but it is a rare cause of retained placenta and is more commonly associated with obstructed labor or mismanaged uterotonics.

Poor maternal pushing efforts (Option D):
The third stage of labor-placental separation-is primarily passive, relying on uterine contractions rather than maternal efforts. Poor pushing may delay delivery of the fetus but is not a significant cause of retained placenta.

choices.text: With manual removal after trying for 5 mins
After 15 min of adequate uterine contraction

questions.text: Diagnosis of retained placenta is made when placenta is not removed
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis of retained placenta is typically made when the placenta fails to deliver spontaneously within 30 minutes after the delivery of the baby, despite uterine contractions and expectant management. This is the widely accepted clinical cutoff, particularly when active management of the third stage of labor is practiced. If the placenta is not expelled by this time, intervention is generally indicated to prevent postpartum hemorrhage and infection.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

With manual removal after trying for 5 mins (Option B):
Manual removal is a treatment, not a diagnostic criterion. It is performed after retained placenta is diagnosed (i.e., after 30 minutes), especially if there is ongoing bleeding or signs of shock.

After 15 min of adequate uterine contraction (Option C):
Although sustained contractions aid placental expulsion, there is no clinical guideline that defines retained placenta based solely on a 15-minute timeline with good contractions. The 30-minute threshold remains standard.

All of the above (Option D):
Incorrect, as only Option A defines the standard diagnostic timeframe. The others are related to management or hypothetical situations.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents to casualty with heavy vaginal bleeding. She had an uncomplicated vaginal delivery 2 weeks back. At present her pulse is 100 bpm BP is 110/70 mmHg. Her laboratory reports reveal Hb 10, TC 7000, no coagulation abnormalities. Most probable diagnosis in her:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely cause of secondary PPH in this context is retained placental tissue, which prevents complete involution of the uterus and leads to delayed or recurrent bleeding. Fragments of placental tissue left in the uterine cavity act as a foreign body and may cause intermittent bleeding, uterine subinvolution, and eventually infection if not treated.

Etiology / Causes:

  • Incomplete separation of placenta during delivery
  • Placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) - abnormally adherent placenta
  • Retained succenturiate lobe
  • Manual removal of placenta with incomplete clearance
  • Previous uterine surgeries (e.g., curettage, myomectomy)

Risk Factors:

  • Prolonged third stage of labor
  • Manual removal of placenta
  • Preterm delivery
  • Uterine atony
  • Placenta previa
  • Previous cesarean section
  • Accessory placental lobes (e.g., succenturiate lobe)

Clinical Features:

  • Persistent or sudden-onset vaginal bleeding after delivery (secondary PPH)
  • Bleeding may be intermittent or continuous
  • Uterine subinvolution (uterus feels larger or softer than expected for postpartum stage)
  • Absence of fever in most uncomplicated cases
  • No foul-smelling discharge unless complicated by infection
  • Normal vital signs or signs of hypovolemia if bleeding is significant

Investigations:

  • Pelvic ultrasound (first-line):
    • Reveals echogenic mass within uterine cavity
    • May show vascularity on color Doppler
  • Complete blood count (CBC):
    • Assess hemoglobin (may be low)
  • Beta-hCG (if diagnosis unclear):
    • To differentiate from gestational trophoblastic disease
  • Coagulation profile (if heavy bleeding)

Management:

Initial Stabilization:

  • Monitor vitals, assess for shock
  • IV fluids and blood transfusion if needed

Medical Management:

  • Uterotonics (e.g., oxytocin, misoprostol) to aid expulsion if bleeding is mild and patient is stable

Surgical Management:

  • Uterine evacuation (Suction and Curettage or Manual Removal under anesthesia)
  • Antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent endometritis

Atonic uterus (Option A):
Uterine atony is the most common cause of primary PPH (within 24 hours of delivery). At 2 weeks postpartum, the uterus is usually well contracted unless disturbed by retained tissue.

Puerperal sepsis (Option C):
This would typically present with fever, foul-smelling discharge, abdominal pain, and elevated WBC count. The patient here has normal vitals and no signs of infection.

Menstrual bleeding (Option D):
Menstrual cycles generally do not resume as early as 2 weeks postpartum, especially in non-lactating women, and are unlikely to cause such heavy bleeding. Also, the bleeding described is abnormal and heavy, inconsistent with typical menstruation.

questions.text: Causes of DIC include all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) is a serious obstetric complication involving widespread activation of the coagulation cascade, leading to consumption of clotting factors, resulting in both thrombosis and bleeding. DIC is typically triggered by events that release tissue thromboplastin or other procoagulant substances into the maternal circulation, causing a systemic coagulation response.

Placenta accreta involves abnormal adherence of the placenta to the uterine wall, but it does not inherently release procoagulant substances or trigger systemic clotting activation. While it can cause postpartum hemorrhage, DIC is not a direct or common consequence unless complicated by other factors (e.g., massive transfusion, infection, or surgical trauma).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Intrauterine fetal death (IUFD) (Option A):
Retention of a dead fetus, especially for more than 2 weeks, can release thromboplastin and trigger DIC.

Abruptio placenta (Option C):
A major cause of DIC. The separation of placenta leads to massive release of thromboplastin into maternal circulation.

Amniotic fluid embolism (Option D):
Rare but catastrophic. Entry of amniotic fluid into maternal blood triggers severe DIC and shock

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient was admitted to the labour room with labour pain. She delivered vaginally without any complications. Immediately after delivery of placenta she developed breathlessness and gasping for air. Her pulse is 120 bpm, BP 80/60 mmHg and SPO2 70%. What is the next best step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 35-year-old woman developed sudden breathlessness, gasping, hypotension (BP 80/60 mmHg), tachycardia (pulse 120 bpm), and desaturation (SpO2 70%) immediately after the delivery of the placenta. This clinical picture is highly suggestive of amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) - a rare but catastrophic obstetric emergency characterized by cardiopulmonary collapse and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

The next best step in such an acutely deteriorating patient is immediate airway protection and cardiopulmonary support - i.e., intubation and resuscitation. Delay in securing the airway and circulation can be fatal. Mechanical ventilation is required to manage hypoxia, and fluid resuscitation and vasopressors are started to treat shock.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Inotropic agents (Option A):
Although inotropes/vasopressors are often required for hypotension, they come after securing the airway. They are part of ongoing resuscitation but not the immediate next step.

Laboratory investigations to check coagulopathy (Option C):
Coagulopathy is a known complication of AFE, but lab work should not delay emergency resuscitation. Investigations are supportive, not immediate lifesaving.

Shift in OT for exploration (Option D):
There is no evidence of surgical cause of bleeding or retained products. Moreover, this patient is hemodynamically unstable and not fit for transfer to the OT until stabilized.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in criteria for diagnosis of Amniotic fluid embolism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is a rare, unpredictable, and life-threatening obstetric emergency caused by the entry of amniotic fluid or fetal debris into maternal circulation, leading to a sudden inflammatory and anaphylactoid reaction. The diagnostic criteria for AFE are clinical and focus on acute cardiorespiratory collapse and coagulopathy, typically occurring during labor, delivery, or the immediate postpartum period.

Fever is not a recognized feature or diagnostic criterion of AFE. It may suggest infection or sepsis, which are separate clinical entities and must be distinguished from AFE.

Core Diagnostic Criteria of AFE include:

  1. Sudden hypotension or cardiac arrest
  2. Acute respiratory distress (e.g., hypoxia, cyanosis, tachypnea)
  3. Coagulopathy or severe hemorrhage (often DIC)

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Hypotension (Option B):
A hallmark of AFE - due to massive vasodilation and myocardial depression.

Coagulopathy (Option C):
Occurs due to activation of clotting cascade, commonly leading to DIC.

Respiratory distress (Option D):
Typically presents as acute hypoxia, cyanosis, or need for ventilatory support.
